To evaluate what is the optimal screening for dyslipidemia to reduce risk of cardiovascular complications in pediatric patients with diabetes
Pediatric patients with diabetes

Screening

  1. Fasting low-density lipoprotein (LDL)
  2. Assessment of family history of cardiovascular disease, age, and puberty

Management/Treatment

  1. Heart healthy diet
  2. Exercise
  3. Monitor low-density lipoprotein (LDL) levels
  4. Inclusion of plant sterols in diet
  5. Statins
  6. Referral to cardiology

FieldValue.Value:
The literature search identified three main guidelines:

  • The American Heart Association (AHA) Scientific Statement that addresses Cardiovascular Risk Reduction in High-Risk Pediatric Patients
  • A Statement from the American Diabetes Association (ADA) regarding the Care of Children and Adolescents with Type 1 Diabetes
  • The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) reporting on Lipid Screening and Cardiovascular Health in Childhood

These guidelines were appraised using the AGREE (Appraisal of Guidelines for Research and Evaluation) instrument and the results by domain were:

AGREE Domain AHA ADA AAP

Stakeholder Involvement 53% 64% 56%

These three guidelines have clear pediatric-focused recommendations that are not directly based on evidence-based outcome data but were generated by consensus expert opinion or extrapolated from adult data. The recommendations developed for this Best Evidence Statement (BESt) are primarily based on a combination of local consensus and recommendations from the AHA guideline.

The strength of the recommendation (strongly recommended, recommended, and no recommendation) and quality of the evidence (1a-5b) are defined at the end of the "Major Recommendations" field.

  1. It is recommended that diabetes patients be screened for dyslipidemia following the algorithm in the original guideline document (Local Consensus, 2010 [5]; Kavey et al., 2006 [5a]; Daniels, Greer, & Committee on Nutrition, 2008 [5b]; Silverstein et al., 2005 [5b]).

    Note: Timing for the first screening is based on age (at least two years), family history for cardiovascular disease (negative history delays need for screening), and puberty (all patients screened not later than puberty regardless of family history) (Local Consensus, 2010 [5]; Kavey et al., 2006 [5a]; Daniels, Greer, & Committee on Nutrition, 2008 [5b]; Silverstein et al., 2005 [5b]).

  2. It is recommended that patients with fasting low-density lipoprotein (LDL) levels greater than 100 mg/dL (milligrams per deciliter) be initially managed with a heart healthy diet, exercise, and monitoring of LDL levels (Local Consensus, 2010 [5]; Kavey et al., 2006 [5a]; Silverstein et al., 2005 [5b]).
  3. It is recommended that patients following a heart healthy diet with fasting LDL levels that persist for six months above 100 mg/dL be educated on the inclusion of plant sterols into their diet (Local Consensus, 2010 [5]; Robinson, 2009 [5a]; Law, 2000 [5a]; Daniels, Greer, & Committee on Nutrition, 2008 [5b]).
  4. It is recommended that patients who continue to have LDL levels >100 mg/dL after following a heart healthy diet and exercise for 12 months, and plant sterols for 6 months:
    • If age ≥10 years: start on statins (males Tanner 2, females past menarche)
    • If age <10 years: be considered for referral to cardiology, based on risk factors and family history (Local Consensus, 2010 [5]; Kavey et al., 2006 [5a]; Silverstein et al., 2005 [5b]).
  5. It is recommended that patients with persistently elevated LDL levels be managed following the algorithm in the original guideline document (Daniels, Greer, & Committee on Nutrition, 2008 [5b]; Silverstein et al., 2005 [5b]).

    Note: Referral to cardiology may be appropriate based on age, family history for cardiovascular disease and other risk factors (Local Consensus, 2010 [5]).

Section.Name: Benefits/Harms of Implementing the Guideline Recommendations

FieldValue.Value:
• The American Heart Association and the American Diabetes Association emphasize the importance of early recognition of elevation of low-density lipoproteins (LDLs) in children with diabetes. Cardiovascular disease, cerebrovascular disease and peripheral vascular disease resulting from atherosclerosis are leading causes of morbidity and mortality among adults with type 1 diabetes and there is unequivocal evidence that atherosclerosis is well established in adolescence with dyslipidemia being the major risk factor. Early education regarding cardiovascular health and early intervention in children with LDL elevation is critical to improving long term outcomes.
  • Although plant sterols are not currently part of the dietary treatment recommendations from the American Diabetes Association in children, the American Heart Association's recommendations suggest plant sterols may be a useful adjunct to therapy. A review of randomized controlled trials of adult participants adding plant sterols to their diet reported a reduction in serum concentration of LDL cholesterol that would be expected to reduce the risk of heart disease by about 25% at an intake of 2 gm per day.

• Side effects of plant sterols are indigestion, constipation and diarrhea.
  • Pharmacotherapy with statins, such as atorvastatin, is Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved in children over 10 years of age. Side effects with statin therapy include diarrhea, arthralgia, and nasopharyngitis. There is also discussion about a risk of elevated liver enzymes (0.2% to 2.3%). The recommendations address this risk with measurement of liver enzymes at baseline and then monitoring every 3 months after starting on statin therapy.

This Best Evidence Statement addresses only key points of care for the target population; it is not intended to be a comprehensive practice guideline. These recommendations result from review of literature and practices current at the time of their formulation. This Best Evidence Statement does not preclude using care modalities proven efficacious in studies published subsequent to the current revision of this document. This document is not intended to impose standards of care preventing selective variances from the recommendations to meet the specific and unique requirements of individual patients. Adherence to this Statement is voluntary. The clinician in light of the individual circumstances presented by the patient must make the ultimate judgment regarding the priority of any specific procedure.
An implementation strategy was not provided.
